review: How does one  the most unique and innovative book he has ever read? More than 1400 others have done so, and I doubt that mine will reveal anythiHow does one  the most unique and innovative book he has ever read? More than 1400 others have done so, and I doubt that mine will reveal anything new. Suffice it to say that this one will stay with me for some time. Abraham Lincoln's son, Willie, died at the age of eleven in early 1862. The nation is less than a year into the Civil War and it has become apparent that it will not be over as easily as many had predicted. Lincoln has already come under criticism for his conduct of the war and he is under constant pressure to resolve the conflict. Willie's death devastated his father, who is reported to have visited his dead son's tomb to sit and grieve over the body. From these historical facts, George Saunders has crafted a story so unique in its telling as to leave the reading wondering "what have I gotten into?"As Willie lays in his crypt, he finds himself in the "bardo", a purgatory, or limbo-like state between life and whatever lies beyond. Others inhabit this space, and it is through them that the story is told. All have died, but refuse to accept their deaths, convinced that their "sickness" will end and they will return to their former life. But only through accepting death can they escape the bardo. While at first longing to remain and see his father, it is Willie who recognizes what he must do to ease his father's grief so that he may address the seemingly insurmountable tasks that face him as President. Engaging and confusing; heart rending and humorous; realistic and magical; some readers may give up on this one. But whether you give up or embrace it to the end, you will not forget it, nor see its equal for some time to come....more

Peppered with observations and the occasional asides about any number of current events and cultural references, the book had me chuckling with every page. By then, I was hooked, and that's when everything changed to what can only be called a "coming of age" story with a unique twist. Most coming of age stories involve a child or teenager, faced with an event that informs their journey into adulthood. In "The Nix", however, the "coming of age" involves a thirty something college professor-failed writer and his sixty something mother who abandoned him some twenty plus years before. Samuel has not heard or seen his mother, Faye, since she abandoned her family. When she is thrust into the national spotlight by an overblown criminal act involving an aspiring presidential candidate, he is forced to confront his memory of her, as well as the apparent contradictions this current event has on that memory. Samuel and Faye have both spent their lives dealing with a "nix", or, to be more precise, many "nixes". Those ideas, infatuations, courses of action, that promise so much happiness and success, only to betray one in the end. How they both resolve the mistakes they have made and come to an understanding of who they really are forms the heart and soul of this remarkable book. Many have criticized, or at least lamented, the length of the book, coming in at more than 600 pages. To be sure, there are a few sections that could well be stand-alone stories in themselves, and might have been shortened or left out entirely. I think this would have been a mistake. Samuel and Faye are on a long journey, so too the reader. Beyond Samuel and Faye, Hill introduces us to a broad range of well developed characters, that, at first, seem to be incidental to the main story, but are all brought together in a remarkably satisfying ending. I often think that there is a hole in our American history, or at least in my knowledge of it. It seems that history books, literature, movies and other media skip over the twenty or thirty years spanning the last decade of the nineteenth century and the first fifteen years of the twentieth. It's like everything slowed down after that gunfight in Tombstone and didn't pick up again until World War I. Yet this was a time when the country was coming of age. The survival of the Union was assured, the continent had been settled all the way to the Pacific, there were forty-eight stars on the flag, and the US was becoming a player on the world stage. It was a time of transition, the blending of the fading old with the emerging new. With this book, Winston Groom has gone a long way to provide us with the sense and "feel" of this often overlooked period in history. With well crafted, easily readable prose, he spins a western yarn of the "good guys pursuing the bad guys", while at the same time, in episodic fashion, alludes to many of the historical events of the era. John Shaughnessy, known as the Colonel, has built a railroad empire. As he has grown older, he has passed much of the management of the business along to his adopted son, Arthur. Like many of their contemporaries, the Shaughnessys also own and operate a large cattle ranch in central Mexico. With the Mexican Revolution raging around them, the American owned ranches have enjoyed a "hands-off" approach from the revolutionaries. That changes when the forces of Pancho Villa kidnap Arthur's daughter and son, the Colonel's grandchildren. With no help coming from the US government, the Colonel and Arthur mount their own rescue mission with a small band of daring cowboys. As they pursue Villa into the Sierra Madre, we meet a host of characters, some historical, others imagined. A rip-roaring, hell-bent for leather tale set in an exciting time in America's history. review: A story of how our own self perception can be affected by how we think others perceive us told with a simple elegance that is a testament to the geniuA story of how our own self perception can be affected by how we think others perceive us told with a simple elegance that is a testament to the genius of Haruki Murakami.As a student in high school, Tsukuru Tazaki makes friends with four others, two girls and two boys, and together they form a strong and inseperable group. They study and work together. They share their secrets, their dreams with each other. They support and encourage the individual talents of each member.But, as supportive and inclusive as the group is, Tazaki continually feels that he is the lesser of the group. For one thing, each of the others have colors in their names, but Tazaki's name is "colorless". Each of the others has a unique talent, but he can find no such talent of his own. All he can do is dream of building train stations, but that can't compare to the talents of his friends.After graduation, Tazaki is the only member of the group to leave their home town for college. The others all attend school close to home and remain in a group. But Tazaki is still considered a member and visits whenever school permits.But in his second year one of the group tells him they no longer wish to associate with him. No reason given, no explanation, no elaboration. Tazaki is devastated and considers suicide, or at least the thought of dying. While he makes it through this period, he becomes more and more convinced that his "colorlessness" has led to his banishment from the group. Sixteen years pass and Tazaki is an engineer building train stations, what he always dreamed of doing. But he continues to perceive himself as "colorless" and finds it difficult to recognize any success in his life.Then he meets Sara, and while previous relationships have come and gone (certainly due to his lack of "color") he desperately wants this one to succeed. He shares his story with Sara and she suggests that it is time for him to recontact his former friends and get to the bottom of why they shunned him. He agrees, and embarks on a journey to find not only the truth, but also is own self worth.As complex as the themes and emotions of the story are, it is amazing how easy this book was to read. It took me longer than I had wanted due to work, but it could easily be read in three or four good sessions. Murakami's prose is simple, but complete. You feel the emotions of the characters. You will want Tazaki to find his "color". An overall good read and a strong four stars. ...more

review: In her Acknowledgments, Mira Jacob comments that it took her ten years to complete he debut novel The Sleepwalker's Guide to Dancing. Let's hope it d In her Acknowledgments, Mira Jacob comments that it took her ten years to complete he debut novel The Sleepwalker's Guide to Dancing. Let's hope it does not take her that long to provide us with more of well crafted prose. Here she has given us characters who can be likeable and unlikeable, often at the same time, and a story that is universal in describing what a family can be. The family is the Eapens, surgeon Thomas, his wife Kamala, who, with their son, Akhil, emigrated from India to New Mexico some thirty years prior. Their daughter, Amina, is born shortly after their arrival. We also meet Thomas' mother and brother in India and a variety of extended family in both countries. Through the first half of the book, we see all the dysfunction that impacts this family. Mothers who attempt to manipulate their children; fathers who concentrate on work at the expense of family; teenagers who rebel against authority; siblings who feel jealous and abandoned; young adults who defy the traditions of their parents. But as the story continues we see that, with all the hurt, heartache and regret, there is a balance here. We find acts of loyalty and respect; of compassion and support; of humor and joy. There is love here, and it binds this family together. Late in the story Amina reflects that she "...found solace in the idea that some things could just fade gently away instead of be analyzed and rationalized and validated. Sometimes, things could just get better." That's how this book should be read. Don't get too hung up on the dysfunction. Cry when you have to, laugh when you can. Relax and let the story happen. Hear the beat, feel the rhythm, enjoy the dance....more
